answers: Gérard De Villefort [accept either underlined part]
Mercedes Mondego [or Mercedes Herrera; prompt on Mondego or Herrera]
parts: Name this character, the chief prosecutor in Marseilles who sends the titular protagonist of the novel he appears in to prison in the Chateau d’If.
Villefort appears in this novel by Alexandre Dumas about Edmond Dantès’ wrongful imprisonment and subsequent quest for revenge.

In The Count of Monte Cristo, this woman is Dantes’ fiancee, who ends up marrying Fernand Mondego and having a son Albert. Upset at this, Edmond very sassily refuses to eat some Muscatel grapes this woman offers him.

answers: atheism [accept equivalents like the nonexistence of god or gods]
parts: Identify this Platonic dialogue which describes the political system that would be established by the title institutions. This is the longest Platonic dialogue.
Book X of The Laws contains an extended argument by the Athenian that uses the soul as the engine of the motion of celestial bodies as evidence against this philosophical position.
The presence of “preludes,” or philosophical justifications, in The Laws differentiates that work from this more famous work by Plato, which contains a notable allegory about a cave.

Name these lipids which are the major component of cell membranes; they traditionally consist of glycerol bound to two fatty acids and a namesake polar head group named for the group 15 element it contains.
Most neutral phospholipids have either ethanolamine or this head group that contains a quaternary amine.
This sugar, commonly found in brain tissue, is the head group of phospholipids like PIP (“pip”). In that lipid this sugar’s phosphorylation state acts as an intracellular signal.

Name this ethnic group that practices the traditional Gadaa (“gad-AH”) system of social stratification, cycling males upward in status every eight years. These people were pejoratively called the “Galla” by rival Amharas and Tigrayans.

Oromos constitute the plurality ethnic group in this African country, which was ruled by a line of emperors from the Solomonic Dynasty until the assassination of Haile Selassie (“HI-lee seh-LASS-ee”).

This current prime minister of Ethiopia joined the Oromo Democratic Party to fight the Derg in the ‘90s. This politician won the 2019 Nobel Peace Prize for resolving Ethiopia’s twenty-year conflict with Eritrea.

answers: lacquer [or lacquerware; prompt on resin; do not accept or prompt on “varnish”]
cobalt [or cobalt-blue; or hui hui qing]
parts: Name this red material made from dried sap that was used to coat cups and bowls during the Ming and Qing dynasties. This material was carved in a technique known as diaoqi.
During the Zhou dynasty, temples were often decorated with bi disks, which were made of this precious green stone and intended to represent the circle of Heaven.

Imported Persian pigments based on this metal led to Jingdezhen (“jing-di-jin”) being the center of porcelain production during the Ming dynasty. Its oxide was used for the underglaze patterning that was then covered with a clear glaze.

answers: order parameter [prompt on m or psi or order]
parts: Name these states of matter which have uniform physical and chemical properties throughout their volume. They include gas, liquid, and plasma.
When a system is in equilibrium, all phases will have the same value for this quantity, symbolized mu. It represents the energy change due to adding another particle to the system.

At vapor-liquid equilibrium, this quantity is equal to the difference in density between the vapor and liquid. This general type of quantity describes which phase the system is in, and usually ranges from zero in one phase to nonzero in another.
Identify this deity who went to Kur to visit Ereshkigal and is escorted out by gallas created from dirt from under Enki’s fingernails. This deity is often accompanied by Ninshubur.
Inanna was worshipped at the Eanna temple in the city of Uruk, once ruled by this hero who rejected her. This friend of Enkidu enlists him to help defeat Humbaba.
This creature resides with a serpent and Lilitu in a tree which Inanna wanted to chop down to make a throne. Ninurta killed this creature for stealing the Tablets of Destiny.

Name this story, in which John Marcher believes that he is destined for a spectacular event lying in wait for him. He realizes he has thrown his life away by failing to realize that May Bartram was in love with him.

The author of "The Beast in the Jungle" also wrote a novella about this free-spirited title character, who is seen as flirtatious because she meets with Giovanelli in the Colosseum and dies from Roman fever.

Novels like Colm Toibin’s The Master have theorized that this author of "The Beast in the Jungle" and "Daisy Miller" was homosexual. He also wrote about the possible ghost of Peter Quint in “The Turn of the Screw.”

answers: Anabaptists [do not accept or prompt on “Baptists”]
parts: Name this city besieged by the exiled bishop Franz von Waldeck. John of Leiden took power in this city after Matthys’ death and executed Elisabeth Wandscherer for opposing his institution of polygamy.

Matthys and John of Leiden belonged to this Christian movement which stated its principles in the Schleitheim Confession and convened a 1550 synod in Venice. The Amish and Mennonites developed as offshoots of this movement.
Matthys identified Münster with the “New [this city].” The Book of Ezekiel declares that this city will be the capital of the Messianic Kingdom where a new King of Israel will be anointed.

answers: Dante Symphony [or A Symphony to Dante’s Divine Comedy; or Eine Symphonie zu Dantes Divina Commedia]
parts: Name this programmatic symphony for orchestra and women’s chorus. The composer had earlier written a “fantasia quasi sonata” inspired by the same source material.
The Dante Symphony was written by this composer and virtuoso pianist, who also composed 19 Hungarian Rhapsodies inspired by Gypsy music.

As a pianist, Liszt freely employed this technique, known by an Italiam name, in which the performer alters the rhythm for expressive purposes, often by slowing down part of a bar and speeding up the rest.

Name this transition metal which is a catalyst for many coupling reactions. A common hydrogenation catalyst consists of this element on carbon, and like platinum it is commonly found in catalytic converters.
Palladium is used in the catalyst in this coupling reaction of an aryl boronic acid and an aryl halide. It is named after a Japanese chemist.
In the Suzuki coupling, halides can be replaced by triflates and other compounds containing these polyatomic ions that react like halides. These polyatomic ions include cyanide and azide.
Name these objects called ghantas (“GHUN-tas”) which hang outside Hindu temples, where people interact with them before entering.
Bells may be adorned with different creatures including an eagle representing Garuda, the mount of this preserver deity.
A bell may be paired with sounds of a conch shell during this part of a puja in which fire is presented to an image of a deity while the congregation sings.

answers: Judge Bao Zheng [accept Judge Bao Gong]
chalk circle [prompt on partial answer, accept Huī lán jì]
parts: Name this magistrate, who appears in many works of gong’an fiction including The Seven Heroes and Five Gallants, and in one work, solves a case where a man is killed by having nails driven into his brain.
In one Judge Bao play, the baby Shoulang is placed in one of these places, where the two potential mothers Hai-tang and Ah-Siu both try to pull him out.
That story inspired The Caucasian Chalk Circle by this fan of classical Chinese drama, the playwright of The Good Person of Szechwan and Mother Courage and Her Children.

answers: Battle of Strasbourg [or Battle of Argentoratum]
parts: Name this Roman emperor of the Constantinian dynasty who published Against the Galileans, a polemical essay about Christianity, and ordered Alypius of Antioch to rebuild the Temple in Jerusalem.

As Caesar, or deputy emperor, Julian crushed an Alemanni army three times the size led by Chnodomar and drove them back across the Rhine at this 357 A.D. battle. Grandsons of Charlemagne took an 842 A.D. oath to oppose their brother Lothair in the city for which this battle is named.

Julian was proclaimed Augustus while stationed with his troops in Lutetia, the Roman name for this modern city. St. Denis, the first Bishop of this city, was executed on a hill here that later came to be known as Montmartre.
This 1976 Palme d’Or winner directed by Martin Scorcese stars Robert De Niro as a man planning to kill a presidential candidate.
This 2004 film directed by Michael Moore is one of only two documentaries that have won the Palme d’Or and focuses on the leadup to the Iraq War.
This New Zealand director is the only woman to have ever won the Palme d’Or, having won for her 1993 film The Piano.

answers: economic stagnation [accept secular stagnation; anti-prompt on stagflation]
parts: Name this condition in which an economy maintains a constant stock of goods and population, aiming for little consumption and almost no economic growth as classically defined.
Economics of the steady-state contrasts with an economics movement that predicts a future in which this condition will end, known as “post-[this condition].”
A steady-state economy is not the same as an economy undergoing this process, which was combined with “inflation” in a portmanteau characterizing late 1970’s economic conditions.

answers: Republic of Ireland [do not accept or prompt on “Northern Ireland”] (The second tax dodge mentioned is the “Double Irish.”)
parts: Name this credit card issued by Goldman Sachs in partnership with a namesake tech company. Its smooth titanium design matches those of its namesake’s popular computers and smartphones.

While integration between the Apple Card, Apple Pay, and the Apple Wallet is a selling point for consumers, it is being investigated as a potential antitrust violation by this Danish regulator, the European Commissioner for Competition.

Vestager also alleges Apple dodged $14 billion in taxes via this EU member country. US companies often use this non-Dutch country in tax schemes like tax inversions, a namesake “Double” BEPS tool, and a “Single Malt.”
Name this lexicographer who published his now-namesake American Dictionary of the English Language in 1828.

Noah Webster lobbied strongly for an 1831 act revising this legal protection delegated to Congress in Article I, Section 8, Clause 8. A 1998 law concerning this legal protection was named for the late Sonny Bono.
Webster studied law under this Connecticut politician who chiefly authored the Judiciary Act. This third Chief Justice promoted ratification of the Constitution in Letters of a Landholder.
Name this “king...in the East,” who “died old.” A story about this man is used to oppose the idea that “malt does more than Milton can / to justify God’s ways to man.”

The story of Mithridates is recounted in this poem, whose narrator mentions “the rate you drink your beer” to the title character before telling him “But oh, good Lord, the verse you make,/ It gives a chap the belly-ache.”
This author of “Terence, this is stupid stuff” also included the poem “When I was One-and-Twenty” in his collection A Shropshire Lad.

answers: robotic surgery systems [or minimally invasive surgery systems; or any combination of the two; prompt on Medrobotics]
parts: Name these devices, which include Intuitive’s Da Vinci machine and Stryker’s Mako. They typically allow results comparable to laparoscopy, but provide higher degrees of freedom with a master-slave system.
Robotic surgery systems are an example of this broad category of devices including catheters and pacemakers, which must be approved by the FDA.

Willem Einthoven invented this medical device, which he tested by sticking his feet into saline water. In this technique, a small box represents 0.04 seconds along its horizontal axis, while a large box represents 0.20 seconds.
